selected_quotes: Fathers-to-be are also at-risk for #anxiety and #depression: #prenatal educational programs may help
Research: Can father inclusive practice reduce paternal postnatal anxiety? Cohort study #midwifery #childbirth
Can father inclusive practice reduce paternal postnatal anxiety? A repeated measures cohort study using the hospital
Can father inclusive practice reduce paternal postnatal anxiety? A repeated measures cohort

citation.abstract: Perinatal research on anxiety and depression has primarily focused on mothers. We have limited knowledge of fathers' anxiety during the perinatal period yet there is evidence that the parenting capacity of a person can be compromised by anxiety and depression. The purpose of this paper is to identify the impact of a father inclusive intervention on perinatal anxiety and depression. The prime focus of the intervention was to provide education and support to fathers of breastfeeding partners with the aim of increasing both initiation and duration of breastfeeding.
citation.title: Can father inclusive practice reduce paternal postnatal anxiety? A repeated measures cohort study using the hospital anxiety and depression scale

facebook.title: Can father inclusive practice reduce paternal postnatal anxiety? A repeated measures cohort study us
facebook.summary: "Paternal anxiety is common to new fathers and providing them with information and strategies for problem-solving can increase their knowledge and potentially lower the risk of postnatal anxiety"

blogs.title: What to expect when you’re expecting – spare a thought for the dads
blogs.summary:
As part of Men’s Health Week and to mark the approach of Fathers’ Day in the UK, we’ve taken a look at some of the research into fatherhood and the often-overlooked anxiety and depression that can be faced by new dads.
